caption: A very fascinating museum about the life of the great sculptor and artist Bourdelle. The museum is really beautiful and has a lot of art and there are rooms where you can learn about this art. The temporary exhibition is also really good. There are 2 small open spaces with a lot of greenery and it's really refreshing and beautiful. This place has an open terrace as well..

The Bourdelle Museum may be small, but it‚Äôs a fascinating place that offers a deep dive into the life and work of the sculptor Antoine Bourdelle. The museum provides an intimate look at his art, showcasing a variety of his sculptures in both indoor and outdoor spaces. Best of all, entry is free, making it a great stop for any art lover.  There‚Äôs also a lovely garden where you can sit and relax after exploring the exhibits. Don‚Äôt miss the souvenir shop‚Äîit has a great selection of gifts and mementos. A charming and enriching experience in the heart of Paris!

What a great exquisite museum in Paris. Oh sorry but I hope this museum doesn‚Äôt get famous, haha because I love it to sitting there in the park just enjoy the magnificent sculptures, sometimes I do the sketch. All the staffs from securities, the receptionists and the cloak room all are very kindly and helpful.

Fascinating to see the work of one of the sculptors who worked for Rodin at one time, and compare the similarities and differences - the current temporary exhibition is worth the money. The restaurant on the first floor serves delicious food.
A quiet small museum that used to be the artist workshop. An opportunity to learn and discover how Big and small statues are done. Very inspiring.

Having seen Bourdelle‚Äôs Herakles in New York, I enjoyed the museum‚Äôs multi-faceted exploration of his life and work. The works are presented beautifully, both outdoors and indoors. There are also interactive displays that you can browse at leisure to learn about Bourdelle‚Äôs journey and his global influence.

Beautiful museum with a garden. I try to go to see Bourdelle‚Äôs masterpieces every time I travel to Paris. He was a successful artist and I love his work. The Greek mythology, the strength in some sculptures like Herakles or Centaure en Mourant are amazing. Part of the museum is indoors and the some pieces are in the gardens of the house that used to be Bourdelle‚Äôs home. The entrance is free and is an accessible museum. I also enjoy it because it‚Äôs not crowded so the approach to the pieces has a more emotional connection

I was not familiar with his work except for The Thinker, which is familiar to many people around the world. He did so many large works fully expressive with emotion. He worked in architectural decoration, before, he was seen as a sculpture in his own right. He studied working in many materials, and the contrasts were interesting to note. I thoroughly enjoyed this  visit and the grounds were lovely. I was happy to be able to see all without becoming exhausted. To note this review was from a previous visit. All answers pertain to my previous visit.
Excellent museum explaining the life and work of the sculptur Bourdelle. Set in beautiful gardens with a cafe upstairs. Free entry.

Extensive museum about an extensive artist, Antoine Bourdelle (1861‚Äì1929). The first time I visited the museum it was years ago. It was good, but thanks to an extension, it is now even better. The interiors and the outdoor spaces are used nicely and creatively. The multimedia means are used appropriately. English speaking visitors are taken into account perfectly. The admission to the permanent collections is free.

Wow, another free to visit museum in Paris focusing on sculpture including some impressive bronzes.  Many of the sculptures are located in the garden which makes them especially delightful to explore on a pleasant weather day.
a lovely and free museum in Paris. Moderately petite with separate galleries. The coffee area is located on the upper floor with a view of the garden below.

It took me around an hour and a half to explore this wonderful museum. I went during the first Sunday of the month and the place is not crowded. I liked the detailed explanation about the process of the bronze statues. Most of the explanations and captions have an English explanation so it is easier to understand. I really learned a lot during this visit.

A delightful mus√©e, full of large and smaller bronze sculptures by Bourdelle, who was an assistant to Rodin, before becoming an artist in his own right. It is FREE. There are also rooms with explanations of the casting process etc.

Upon entering this museum I wasn‚Äôt sure, at first, that I would like it. However, as I began examining these sculptures in more detail I became increasingly drawn to Bourdelle‚Äôs work. Many of his sculptures are very engaging, asking the viewer to imagine the people depicted and to examine their lives and their stories. It was perhaps the ‚ÄúMask of Beethoven‚Äù that left the deepest impression but there were a number of others, also, that will long remain with me. Each of us must discover his or her own.

What a gem üíé I‚Äôve just discovered one of my favorite small museums in Paris‚Ä¶ and it‚Äôs FREE !! This is a must see. The photos do not do it justice. There‚Äôs a great interactive section for learning. Enough said. ‚Ä¶
Love this amazing musee and it‚Äôs for free !!

I really enjoyed visiting this museum. The visit is free, stimulating, and approachable. The museum isn‚Äôt too big (you won‚Äôt get lost and you‚Äôll have time to see everything). The employees are kind, the garden is lovely, and there is also a caf√© upstairs (where you can also have lunch).

this museum is small but bursting with beautiful sculpture. the exhibits are thoughtful and informative! it is also interesting to peek into the various studios to get a glimpse into how bourdelle lived and worked.  it‚Äôs also free and there is a free coat check! the caf√© on the terrasse is lovely as well.

Beautiful works of sculptural art await you in this delightful (and free) museum. The size and scope of the sculptures are diverse and incite the imagination. Plan on spending as a minimum one to two hours exploring Antoine Bourdelle's works. The Rhodia Cafe, located on the premises, offers healthy menu options and friendly and efficient service. We visited the museum on a Friday. (It is closed on Mondays.)
The museum had many examples of the sculptures crafted by Bourdelle. Interpretive signage included English. Some displays were interactive and touching was encouraged. There is a Cafe in the museum.

It might be free but I would have gladly paid. First you enter a small garden with monumental statues without context. Inside the artist's studios you get more explanation. The exit is through the garden again and you look at them again, betterinformed this time. Lovely gem of a museum.

My most favorite mus√©e in Paris. It‚Äôs smaller than Rodin but less touristy, and because of that it‚Äôs more serene and feels more intimate. I especially love Bourdelle‚Äôs atelier. The interior feels like the perfect fit for his work to be put there. The ambience, the colors of the walls, the sunlight from its paneled windows ‚Äî everything creates the mood just right. A must visit in Paris!

Located near Montmartre station, the Musee Bourdelle was the studio of one of ‚ÄúFrance‚Äôs greatest sculptors‚Äù but to me the museum sure didn't convey that. It seemed very poorly designed. He was a philanderer and enjoyed painting his muses but his paintings were of questionable skill. The garden had several of his sculptures and I liked them; I wish there had been more emphasis on his sculpture. Overall the museum - and him - left me bored. Good thing it was free!

Love it! Well curated museum with works and history of the artist beautifully presented. Took me by surprise what I could take away from it. Not just about appreciating the sculptures, but also understanding the different sculpturing techniques presented in a visually engaging way. And the plus point, that it‚Äôs a free entry museum. Worth a visit!
Great sculpture museum with many works on display, Bourdelle was a master and his school taught many students.  Many of his works are huge and displayed in 2 outdoor gardens.
It was an excellent discovery for me. Except the temporary exhibition, the entrance is free of charge. Each space is very special. The restaurant seems very nice. It is to come back several times.
Fabulous! Probably the most beautiful sculpture garden I‚Äôve ever been in. It is in a small and intimate and absolutely lovely.

It is a nice museum if you are into sculptures!   I found the studio is very well organised and you can learn the process of how a huge sculpture is built.  There is also an interactive digital screen where you can learn some fun facts about the famous ‚ÄúHercules the Archer‚Äù.

If you find yourself in Paris with some spare time then I would suggest you have a look at the Bourdelle museum in Montparnasse. The museum is free and takes you through the works of Antoine Bourdelle, a sculptore extraordinaire. He was a student of Rodin and taught amongst others Matisse. There is a marvellous little garden at the front where you can soak up some sun whilst admiring some of his work if you want to take it easy. Otherwise you can easily spend an hour or so walking around the museum and his old studio. Don't miss the garden path at the back for some of his work in a nice setting. A great and free museum at the heart of the city.
Visited on Saturday. This man! Wanted to pass on his works and collection to the next gen. Great garden, cozy cafe, historical contents.

Superb museum if you're an aspiring artist. Lots of material to draw from. Bourdelle was a very prolific artist, so you'll have loads of subjects here. Your mileage may vary depending on if you want to spend time analyzing the sculptures, but most of them are of very high quality. I was also astounded by the size of the statues in the side hall. Really recommend the visit!
Could not believe this is free! Great little museum with displays mainly in the gardens. The cafe is very good. Deserves to be much better known.
Beautiful museum showcasing many of Antoine Bourdelle‚Äôs work. It is set in his house, studio and garden. The sculptures are magnificent and inspiring. Highly recommended.

Nearby Montparnasse train station, this museum is free but the special exhibition (dedicated to back dress fashion). Mainly dedicated to sculptures from Bourdelle and other masters. It has little gardens and courtyards hiding quite interesting pieces

The Mus√©e Bourdelle is magnificent! The beautiful courtyard and garden walk way housing Antoine Bourdelle's sculptures is a perfect backdrop for a peaceful awe inspiring afternoon. The sculptures in the gallery are breathtaking.  Currently (July-November 2019) Palais Galleria is showing an exhibit celebrating fashion from behind...garments with the focus on the back. Absolutely magical! This little gem in the 15th arrondissement is a must visit when in Paris for those of us who prefer a more intimate museum experience.

I recommend this museum to anyone who is interested in sculpture and wants to make the visit in a calm and peaceful environment. The entrance to the permanent exposition was absolutely free (to our surprise). The museum is absolutely beautiful, not very big, you can make finish your visit in about 1 hour. There are a lot of impressive art pieces worth seeing and an amazing atelier. It really gives you a glimpse into the creative process. You can make photos, but no video recording is permitted (at least in the atelier).
Great small museam, off the beaten track, definitely worth a visit.
